claim: If you watch a pot of water on the stove, it will boil.

supporting.text: Watching a pot of water on the stove does not affect the boiling process, as boiling is determined by heat transfer and atmospheric pressure.

attacks.text: Watching a pot of water on the stove does not affect the boiling process, as boiling is determined by heat transfer and atmospheric pressure.
Human observation can indirectly affect boiling time by adjusting heat settings or reacting to visual cues (e.g., bubbles forming).
Heat adjustment due to observation is negligible in controlled experiments where heat input is constant.
The claim implies psychological time perception (watched pots seeming to boil slower), not physical boiling dynamics.
Psychological effects are subjective and do not alter the physical truth of the boiling process.

supporting.text: A pot of water on the stove will boil when sufficient heat is applied, regardless of whether it is being watched.

attacks.text: A pot of water on the stove will boil when sufficient heat is applied, regardless of whether it is being watched.
Watching the pot may indirectly affect boiling time by causing the observer to adjust heat or lid placement.
Human intervention (heat/lid adjustment) is not inherent to watching - the core physical process remains unchanged.
Quantum mechanics suggests observation can influence physical systems at microscopic scales.
Macroscopic systems like boiling water are decohered from quantum observer effects.

supporting.text: The act of watching a pot of water does not provide the energy required for boiling, which comes from the stove's heat source.

attacks.text: The act of watching a pot of water does not provide the energy required for boiling, which comes from the stove's heat source.
Watching the pot may indirectly ensure the heat source remains active, preventing accidental shutoff or adjustment.
Modern stoves often have automatic shutoff features or timers, reducing the need for direct observation to maintain heat.
The claim is metaphorical, suggesting that excessive focus on an event may make it seem slower, not about physical causation.
Even metaphorically, the perception of time is subjective and doesn't change the physical boiling process.

supporting.text: Boiling is a physical process dependent on temperature and pressure, not on observation.

attacks.text: Boiling is a physical process dependent on temperature and pressure, not on observation.
Observation can indirectly affect boiling by ensuring the heat source remains active and consistent.
Even without observation, modern stoves and kettles have automatic shut-off features to prevent overheating.
In quantum mechanics, observation can influence physical processes (observer effect), though this is negligible at macroscopic scales.
The observer effect in quantum mechanics does not apply to classical thermodynamic processes like boiling water.
